blocks.text: More than a foot of snow in mid-January. Cindy and Kathy in the front driveway of our home.
February 8, 1964 – After almost twenty one years of association, Gordon and Educators Mutual Life part company over basic policy differences.

March 6 - 8, 1964: At the Rohrbach cottage, Lake Wallenpaupack, in the Poconos: John and Emmie Rohrbach; John and Polly Rohler; Wally and Claire Pringle; Dave and Billie Ross; Annabelle Hamaker; Gordon and Kitty. Snow along the Lake frontage.

blocks.text: Grist mills continue to stand today in all parts of Lanc. County as evidences of early industry. Some are still in operation. It is believed there was a total of at least 240 mills in the county by 1840. They were community centers where gossip and politics were topics of discussion. The miller was generally a man of money and influence in the community.
Billie Ross and Kitty.

blocks.text: June 30, 1964 – Nancy and Cindy fly from Kennedy National Airport to Europe for summer's vacation...get delivery of new V-W in Germany. Nancy scheduled to return in late August; Cindy to remain in Europe for a year if job becomes available.

Everything is in readiness (left) as Gordon and Kitty prepare to drive them to New York; (right) Cindy and Nancy say good-by as departure nears. Gordon almost misses seeing them off when not one parking space is available, and finally leaves car in unloading zone ($5 fine, but worth it).
A final waving good-by under the wing of the Irish International plane, as they prepare to board.

blocks.text: After the plane departs, Gordon and Kitty drive to Bayside, L. I. to spend the night with Stu and Gladie Cunningham. The next day a one-day inspection of the New York World's Fair, in its first year. The temperature is 99 degrees...leave in late afternoon...drive into Connecticut for night...return home through the Poconos.

blocks.text:
Aug. 23, 1964 - Nancy returns from Europe.
(Cindy remains in Paris; job with UNESCO.)
Gordon follows Nancy with the camera as she alights from the plane and proceeds through Customs. Long package is three loaves of French bread, baked that morning in Paris.

blocks.text: By late September Gordon and Kitty find themselves alone at home: Nancy teaching in Arlington, Va; Cindy in Paris; Kathy at M/V State; but living at Weaver home to help with children; Louise at Bowling Green University. Great change.

Nancy on frequent trips to Lancaster, shown at different times with week end guests at our home: (left) with Carolyn Brown; (right) with Steve Wordell, soon to leave for Europe on new business assignment.
Lancaster County's superlative farm land in early fall.
With all four girls away from home, Kitty returns to teaching after a lapse of almost twenty five years...5th grade, Wharton School, in Lancaster city.

Cindy calls long distance from Athens, Greece, where she is on vacation.

blocks.text: The year 1965.
Newspapers report January freeze in Lancaster County longest in 50 years.
Kathy returns to Lancaster from Port Chester New Year's day with the Connollys. where she spent New Year's dday within three Cooonnollys.
Louise will fly back to Bowling Green to finish final month of her first semester.
Nancy loads her V-W with furniture for new apartment at 4000 Tunlaw Rd., in Washington, D. C.
Mid-January: Kitty in car for trip to Villanova for Week end with Demis.

blocks.text:
January 26–27, 1965: Gordon, accompanied by Kathy, drives to Bowling Green to bring Louise home at the conclusion of her first semester. She will not return.
Although Louise's grades are excellent (Dean's list), she is unhappy at Bowling Green...will see ktransfer to Penn State.
After getting Louise, encounter snow and ice in northwestern Ohio. Motel at Tiffin.
Examples of some of the unusual architecture in central Ohio.

blocks.text: Cornwall, the town and furnace, located in Lebanon County, pre-date the Revolutionary War. Here is found one of best examples of early Penna ironworks, which supplied cannon to Washington's army.

The original company town still fully inhabited, suggests a town in Old England.
Ennglaand.
The open mine pit where ore is obtained to this day was at one time the largest in the United States.
The furnace, in operation from 1742 to 1883, now a state shrine, is open to visitors.
Old sandstone church where services continue to be held.

blocks.text: The Welsh came early to Lanc. county, settled Caernarvon Twp., Bangor Church, Church-town, said to date from 1722; present building from 1879. Several Revolutionary War soldiers buried in graveyard. Name of Evans prominent among early settlers.

South of Churchtown is Windsor Forge, one-time home of Blanche Nevin. the artist. The large stone Buddha in front of the house was probably shipped here from India during one of her extensive travels.
Birthplace of Robert Fulton (1735) south of Quarryville.
Gordon and Kitty on a drive through the river hills of York county.

blocks.text: March 23, 1965 - Louise enrolls as a student at Penn State University... Gordon drives her and car full of clothing and assorted equipment to University Park.
Kitty, who is teaching, says good-by and good luck.

Louise's room is 408 East Hall, a new dormitory near football field. ...a few students have returned for new term...almost alone in building as Gordon follows her to unload...as roommate will follow in several days.
Gordon stays the night at Taylor Motel. returns next day.

Traces of snow in the mountains near Penn State.
State.
( Opposite page) Louise gets acquainted with the Nittany Lion.

blocks.text: May 22, 1965 - Cindy returns home from Paris after eleven months abroad.
Kathy and Jon arrive in Lancaster the night before...go along to greet Cindy.

Excitement at Kennedy Airport...Cindy's plane a half hour early...she finds us, after already thru Customs, on observation platform watching later TWA passengers alight, but no Cindy...impression she had missed her flight.

Kitty and Louise watch Nancy's plane take off from Friendship Airport, near Baltimore...to Chicago, to Mexico City and Guadalajara.

July 10 - 11: to Scranton to visit Simonsons...afternoon at Wells' cottage (Gordon Simonson, left).

blocks.text: July 17 - 18: Jack and Mary Connolly visit Gordon and Kitty in Lancaster. Pictures at Sunday picnic in Robinsons' yard.

July 13 - 15: Gordon and Kitty on first visit to Kathy and Jon's new apartment in Larchmont, N. Y. Kathy shows Gordon newly purchased '58 Thunder-bird. Jon at National Guard summer camp.

blocks.text: Aug. 20, 1965 - Nancy returns from Mexico after post-school travels to Mexico City and Acapulco. Shown with some of her trophies collected in various parts of Mexico.

Daniel Croz, friend,
of Cindy's in Paris.
is week end guest
while on quick tour
of U. S. & Canada.
Aug. 28 - Gordon on birthday checks slow growth of gingko tree, planted several seasons ago...decides it must be dwarf variety.
The Landreth family gets together as a group for the first time in four-teen months...Louise, Cindy, Gordon, Kitty, Jon Connollylly, Kathy & Nancy. August 28, 1965.

blocks.text: September 8, 1965 - Kitty on front steps for official birthday picture.

September 11-12, 1965 - Gordon, Kitty, Nancy and Louise drive to Port Chester, N. Y. for visit with Jack and Mary Connolly, John and Kathy. Shown also are John's sister, Mira, and Mary's father, "Chief".

September 22 - Louise loads the trunk of
the car once again for trip to Penn State
to begin her sophomore year. She waves
good-by to Gordon from in front of Wolf
Hall where she will be lodged as a pledge
of Kappa Alpha Theta. Cindy lived here
during most of her undergraduate days.

blocks.text: September 23, 1965 - Gordon, accompanied by James, drives Bill and Arline Robinson to Kennedy International Airport for flight to Italy as first part of vacation trip to the Mediterranean Islands and Greece. Recently completed Verrazano Narrows Bridge.
Picnic at Caledonia State Park with Sam and Marian Rohrer, Ike and Marilyn Groff. Gordon and Kitty provide the lunch.

Kitty, near Mt. Gretna, late September.

mneearrrr Mnt.

blocks.text: HOW ARE THES BE HONEYBEE Busy Bees The Honeybee WHAT CAN YOU DO OVER There are so many wonderful things to learn about bees why don't you read Some of these books and see?
The Honeybee.

(Left) In early October, Gordon and Kitty visit Nancy and Cindy in Washington... first visit to Nancy's school, McKinley Elementary, in Arlington, where Nancy is a third grade teacher...Cindy with her roommates in new apartment on 20th St.... frame of large apartment building that is rising across from Nancy's apartment on Tunlaw Rd.
On October 12, 1965 Cindy observes her 24th birthday...is employed in Washington by National Educational Radio.

blocks.text: Lancaster Chapter of American Business Clubs celebrates 40th anniversary. Gordon presents gifts from the chapter to two charter members, S. Ernest Kilgore and George S. Kutz (newspaper photograph).

Kitty is embarked on her second year as a fifth grade teacher in the Wharton School as in Lancaster City....has 41 pupils this year. Note newspaper clipping of A. B. C. presentation (above) in the "Wharton Weekly" that Kitty is holding.

blocks.text: One of the oldest graves in Lancaster County at Chestnut Level Levellin., contains graves early settlers who died before start Revolutionary War.
A little travelled road south of Christiana along the Oct-orator Creek offers some of the most picturesque scenery in Lancaster County on a bright autumn day.

Graves of Gordon's Father and Mother in Ream's Cemetery, a short distance south-west of Reamstown, Pa. Gordon's Father was born near Madison, North Carolina.
Also in Ream's Cemetery, the graves of Gordon's Grandmother and Uncle Tom Evans.

T. Frank Evans was Gordon's maternal Grandfather.
He is buried in the Lititz Cemetery. The house (above) on North Broad St., Lititz, was built by him after he married Clara Lesher, Reamstown,
Gordon’s Mother was born here.
Caption: .

The by-pass around Lancaster
is being extended from
Rohrersstown to Mountville...
is scheduled to be opened in
the spring of 1966.
Farm in the hills along the Pequea Creek on little-used road near Marticville.
The shortest covered bridge in Lancaster County is at Oreville, over the Little Conestoga Creek, visible from the Old Harrisburg Pike.

The shortest covered bridge in Lancaster County is at Oreville, over the Little Conestoga Creek, visible from the Old Harrisburg Pike.

blocks.text:
December 18–22, 1965: Gordon makes a personal business trip to West Bend, Wisconsin, to see an official of B. C. Ziegler and Company, specialists in institutional bonds.
First day – Lancaster to Tiffin, Ohio Miles 432
Second day – Tiffin to Bristol, Wis. 353
Third day – Bristol to West Bend, to Port Washington, return to West Bend .
Fourth day – West Bend to Tiffin, Ohio 103 397
Fifth day – Tiffin to Lancaster 425
Total miles 1,710
All set to leave early Saturday morning; Kitty gets the picture.

The Lincoln Highway to the Penna. Turnpike at Breezewood...brief stops at Gettysburg...the Peace Light, with its perpetual flame, and equestrian statue of Lancaster's General Reynolds, who was killed on the first day of the battle.
ROAST BEEF
Darkness falls in eastern Ohio...a quick bite to eat at Arby's...roast beef, 69¢, plus hot cider with cinnamon for l¢.

Across two-thirds of Ohio after dark - to a motel near Tiffin. Little else to do, so Gordon snaps a picture in the motel.
Little tittle oohio hoia hooihoiohio ahio hiihiiohio daakrk - to a mottell tell nesear nesear nesear nesear nesear nesear.

blocks.text:
After leaving West Bend at noonn,
Gordon drives almost 400 miles
to spend that night at the same motel near Tiffiin, Ohio.

The old Good Year dirigible shed in Akron,
built to house an airship that has vanished
in our generation.
The Pennsylvania Turnpike at New Stanton. From here Gordon drives old route 30 as far as Bedford, the better to enjoy the mts.
As darkness closes in, a final supper stop at the Ship Hotel, built on the side of the mountain, not far from Bedford.
End - trip to Wisconsin.

blocks.text: The holidays are ended...
John and Kathy. off for Larchmont.
Louise returns to Penn State to begin the second term of her sophomore year...Kitty says good-by...at PS, ready to move into her room at Wolf Hall just before Gordon leaves for home.

"Baron" Stiegel. iron and glass maker extraordinary. is an almost legendary figure in Lancaster County. Stiegel glass, made in Manheim just prior to the Revolutionary War. is today highly prized by collectors.
The War impoveriished Sttiegel and left him in debt. Charming Forge in Berks County discovered by Gordon by chance, apparently was his last business attempt. and here he died in 1785.

blocks.text: January 17. 1966 - Lancaster Chapter of American Business Clubs inspects the recently completed plant of Pensu Supreme, processors and manufacturers of dairy products, on the outskirts of Lancaster.

The main entrance...plant is said to be one of the most modern of its kind in the U. S.
The plant is said to have been built by a company called Ecntrancerecncenee...plant, and it was completed around 1964-1966. The facility is considered one of the most advanced plants of its type in the United States at that time.
The milk packaging section.
Sam Rohrer. who is personnel manager with the guide and hostess.

blocks.text:
January 29–31, 1966 - Gordon and Kitty to Larchmont, N. Y. to visit Kathy and John
...encounter one of worst snow storms in recent years on return trip...especially last 50 cars stranded along New Jersey Turnpike ...find Penna. Turnpike completely closed ...try to reach home through Philadelphia ...no chance...find motel at NJTurnpike exit...one day late try again to get home via PaTurnpike...open only to Valley Forge
...manage to reach Paoli over route 202...and Coatesville before closed by drifting snow...arrive home 4:30 p.m. to find more snow in Lancaster than anywhere else.
Kathy before Rye Neck school where she teaches 6th grade.
John tries his hand at pool, afternoon party near Greenwhich Conn.
Mira Connolly leaves for home with Chuck and Mary Brown.

Gordon and Kitty enter windswept NJTurnpike after dark. At time snow effaces all objects. Highway fairly well cleared, but slippery. Speed never exceeds 35 mi. per hr. Reach PaTurnpike, to find it closed for only fourth time in its history.
Snowball fight between John and Kathy as the snow continues to fall. Kitty is impartial spectator.
